Fields.DialogueText: Argonaut, is that you? You've been so hard to find!
Ah, Captain, it's divine to see you. I've been occupied for the last few days looking over this new script.
There's a war on, Argonaut. You can't just disappear like that. We have three days' worth of strategic briefings to cover.
Oh, Captain, how dreary! Surely Mr. Barchet can handle such things? Isn't that his job, after all?
We have these briefings for a reason, Argonaut. Your attendance isn't optional.
Was I consulted in that? No. It's quite rude, Captain. Honestly, I expected better from you.

Fields.MenuText: ... Maybe it's better if you don't come to the briefings.
Rude or not, you have a job to do here. And you need to start doing it.
I didn't want to admit this, but I need you at the briefings to help inspire the sailors.

Fields.DialogueText: How dare you, Captain! I shall see you at the next one bright and early, and you will be thankful I arrived.
Oh, I think I do my job very well, Captain. I scarcely need your approval on my own decks.
Ah, say no more, Captain. My particular style of radiance is hard to match.
Very well. Is that the alarm? It looks like we'll have to table this discussion.
And I was finally getting into character! Very well. I will suffer for my art.
@BATTLE
Argonaut? Mr. Barchet said I could find you back here.
Did he? That welsher! He was supposed to be holding my meetings while I worked on costuming.
It turns out that being captain is a good way to get what you want around here.
Well, I do hope you aren't too upset by disappointment. Tell me, do you think this fleece stole would go with that top?
I don't care. You're supposed to be on patrol, and you've been sitting idle for four hours now.
Well, you can't very well expect me to go out unless I have an outfit to not be seen in, can you?

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't begin to make sense.
I expect you to go on patrol when you're expected to go on patrol, and not put the fleet in jeopardy over an outfit.
Look, the top is fine. Just get out there and start hunting.

Fields.DialogueText: I certainly wouldn't expect a military lout like you to understand, Captain.
Oh, please - you can't expect me to patrol looking like some haggard witch. One must have standards, Captain.
Oh, you're just saying that. I need a real opinion. Now where are those boys?
There's the alarm again. It looks like someone's actually doing their job.
You seem bitter, Captain. I can't fathom why.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Ah, yes, Captain, thank you for waiting. I simply had to finish powdering. It would be unbecoming of a lady to...
You're on fire.
Oh, Captain, I do say, while interruptions are not particularly polite, I do like hearing...
You are literally on fire. Why is there a fire inside a submarine?
Oh, poo. That? It's just one of those things, you know. Our little cross to bear.
There's a fire inside a pressurized metal tube. Why is no one concerned about this?
Oh, fine, you worrywart. Mr. Barchet, would you please send someone in to put out this fire? Yes, in the electrical system again.

Fields.MenuText: Do you need an overhaul or something? You really shouldn't be catching on fire like this.
Don't you have a fire suppression protocol or something? This shouldn't have been down to me to catch.
Well, now that that's over with... I have completely forgotten why I can down here to talk to you.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain! The very idea! Although I wouldn't say no to those new propellers. They do look stylish, don't they? Maybe painted gold?
Oh, no, it happens often enough that whoever's nearby usually handles it. It's more of a pest, really.
Oh, a lot of people come to see me for reasons they can't quite name. Don't worry about it too much - although I would appreciate it if you'd refrain from wasting my time in the future.
...Oh, right! Enemy fleet movements have been detected. We'll be engaging within the hour.
Just enough time to finish my hair. Thank you for the advance notice, Captain.
@BATTLE
I have to admit, Argonaut, it was nice to see you actually enthusiastic about taking a patrol for once.
Why of course, Captain. One must do one's part for the cause and all that. And I daresay the locals deserve our protection.
Funny you should say that. I have some reports that you made a few unscheduled stops at the local ports.
Captain! Are you implying I'm neglecting our mission? For shame!
Not at all. It just seems that you were making a point of... being seen, I guess. Your fashion sense made quite an impression, by the way.
Oh, yes, well, I may have made appearances at a couple of docks. Purely for morale purposes, of course.

Fields.MenuText: The point of a patrol is to gather information for us, not to give it to others.
Next time, save your sightseeing for another trip, all right?
Morale isn't on the agenda today, Argonaut. Maybe you can find time to show off later.

Fields.DialogueText: I got plenty of information. I can even take a guess at the next season of the local fashion.
It's not sightseeing, Captain! If anything, it's sight showing.
How dare you, Captain! I'm not "showing off!" I am an engine of beauty and grace providing relief from the darkness of war.
Duly noted. For what it's worth, the patrols have been fairly productive - we're closing in on another Morgana scouting party now.
Why didn't you lead with that, Captain? I need to change.
@BATTLE
Argonaut, what did you do?
Whatever do you mean, Captain? I completed my patrol as scheduled, and even found time for a little extra work.
I had assumed you would be pleased at my efficiency, after all of your complaints about lollygagging.
You dumped mines all along your patrol route! We have to reroute the entire fleet now!
Ah, but I have denied that route to the enemy, have I not? And is that not important to the war effort?
Your report states that you didn't see a single sign of enemy activity on your patrol!
All the more reason to keep them out of that area, I'd say. Seems like I did us all a favor.

Fields.MenuText: You can't just make decisions like that! You're endangering the fleet.
How is blocking our major route of advance in any way helpful to us?
I'm starting to think I'd be better off just holding you in the center of the fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: The nerve! I would never endanger the fleet!
Well, you see... hmmm. Well, it's blocked for the enemy too, isn't it?
Ah, a wise decision, Captain! Then everyone could benefit from my company.
We'll talk about this later. We've got enemy movement in the route you didn't block off.
@BATTLE
Officer Barchet tried pretty hard to not tell me where you were. Why are you hiding in the engine room?
Because I can't mess anything up here, obviously.

Fields.MenuText: Sure you can, if you put your mind to it. There's tons of breakable stuff in here.
Are you whining because of the mine thing? Because that's unbecoming of a warship.
Why are you taking it so hard? I figured you could handle criticism by now.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a terrible way to make me feel better.
Well, maybe you're unbecoming of a captain. I just wanted to help.
What is that supposed to mean? Because I'm such a mess... up?
You've managed to make it very clear, very quickly, that I can't seem to perform to your standards.
As such, I don't see what it matters to you where I am or what I'm doing. So why don't you leave me alone?
Because you're a warship, and you're a part of this fleet. Like it or not, we've got a job to do out here.
Well, for the record, I don't like it. It's humiliating and beneath me.
For the record, I don't care. Now as long as you're here, spin the engines up. We have an enemy to fight.
@BATTLE
I wanted to applaud you for actually taking the time to attend the briefings lately.
Mm... hmm.
I noticed you kept quiet during the briefing.  Was there anything you wanted to contribute to the strategy?
No.
Is there anything you'd like to say at all? We've got a good plan coming together, but we could always use your input.
No, thank you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You really aren't giving me much to work with here.
Now would be a very good time to stop being childish. You've been making such progress.
I really liked the hat you wore to the briefing. Quite fetching, I thought.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I suppose I'm not.
No, thank you, Captain.
Thank you. I thought it went rather well with the season.
Well, I'll see you at the next briefing, I suppose.
Feel free to disregard my senses, Captain, but... I think we might have other business you should attend to.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you have a minute? I had something I'd like to speak to you about.
Hmm? Oh, Barchet. Of course! Is something the matter with Argonaut?
Well, yes and no. The old girl's been a little temperamental lately, and I thought you might be helpful in getting her back to her old self.
Yes, I saw the fires and such. Very well. What can I do to help? It's important that my ships are in full working order.
Oh, that? Those were normal fires. I meant the moping. She doesn't really feel like she fits in in the fleet, Captain.
What? Normal fires? And what do you mean she doesn't fit in? We're not exactly a country club.
Well, you see, sir, she...
Well, hello there, officers. What are you two talking about?

Fields.MenuText: Ah, over the silent treatment, I see. Glad to hear I'm not being hated forever.
Only your effervescent beauty and remarkable personality, of course.
Nothing!

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Captain, such ego to think you could affect me so. I wish I had half your bravado.
A perfect topic! Do go on. I would love to hear more.
Hurrumph, fine. Be that way. Mr. Barchet, charmed, as ever.
Oh, listen, an alarm! Let's go fight a war.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Argonaut, I've been thinking, and I'd like to try something with you.
Oh, Captain, I'd love to give you some lessons, but I'm ever so busy with my own practice, and I don't want to skip a reading.
No, that's not...
Although I suppose I can be persuaded to allow you to sit in on the next script reading. What do you say to that?
I actually wanted to ask you for...
I know, I know, but I'm just so busy! Why don't you talk to Mr. Barchet and we'll see if we can find you a chair.

Fields.MenuText: No, this is about tactics...
I wanted to see if you'll...
Why don't you wait a...

Fields.DialogueText: Oh. Well, I really prefer warming up with vocal exercises. I'll get that on the agenda for you.
Please, Captain, it's unbecoming to beg. I'll make sure you're well taken care of.
No time, Captain, no time! I simply must have my next costume finished by this evening or it will disrupt my whole schedule.
You need to wait just a...
Oh, and there's the alarm. Captain, I'll have a schedule sent to you afterwards.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, Argonaut, take a moment. I need to talk to you.
Ah, Captain, you're here early! Eager for the acting lessons, I can only assume?
Well, yes, but I had something else to discuss if you think you can spare the time.
Of course, Captain, I always have time for you. What can I do to help you and the fleet?
I wanted to talk to you about finding a better fit for you amongst the fleet. You don't seem to be enjoying the patrols and such.
I'm wondering if we might want to find you a role that makes better use of your talents.
Am I not doing a good job, Captain? Are you saying I need to be replaced?

Fields.MenuText: No, of course not. I just wanted to make sure you were doing something you found fulfilling.
I was actually rather hoping you'd replace someone else, and do a better job in their position.
Exactly. And I want to put you somewhere where you will do a good job.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, thank you for your care, Captain! I'm certain there's a better space for me somewhere in the fleet than simple patrols.
Show someone how it's done, hmm? Well, as long as it doesn't cut into my rehearsal time.
Harrumph. Well, Captain, I suppose we'll just have to see, shall we?
We'll have to talk more another time.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Indeed! I do so hate missing an opportunity to explore my favorite subject.
Yourself.
Myself! You're always so perceptive.
Red leather, yellow leather. Red leather, yellow leather. That is hard to say quickly.
I told you the acting workshop would be interesting. And I'm certain I saw you having fun.
I'll admit that I was nervous, but you were all very welcoming. And I think I did pretty well.
Don't get too cocky, darling. You did passably well for a first time - but wait until you see me and Mr. Barchet in an improvisational workshop.
I was not expecting the crew to be so lively during the exercises. And it seemed to be a good event for mingling.
It certainly puts all of the crew on an even footing. And I can help all of them equally, after all.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose I'll be attending the next one as well, if you'll have me.
Regardless, it's an event I was happy to be a part of.
I can certainly see why. Your acting talents blow the rest of ours out of the water.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, of course, Captain! I wouldn't dream of excluding you.
Oh, do say you'll come to the next one, Captain! We've got a lovely idea for collaborative storytelling.
I am a film actress, after all. It's to be expected.
Well, there's the alarm. Time to show those Morganas what we've got.
Places, everyone! Time for the show!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, Argonaut, I appreciate you attending the strategic briefings. But in case you missed it, we have a new job for you.
Oh, lovely, Captain! What a surprise this is! Do tell?
I thought as much. Well, we're going to adopt a more defensive strategy for a bit, and we thought we might make use of your mine laying capabilities.
Ah, fantastic, Captain! I can lay some right now if you'd like. It'd be no trouble, I promise!
How about you hold off for just a bit. But I've got a nice map with the areas I would like filled with mines.
Oh, I see. Well, I suppose I can do as you ask. Shouldn't be too much trouble.

Fields.MenuText: No, I mean you can you create your own minefields however you want. I just need them in the right place.
Come on, chin up. You'll get to show off your skills for the whole fleet. And we'll all be thankful when the enemy is funneled into our sights.
I'm glad to hear it, Argonaut. This will be a major asset in our fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, well, that sounds nice then. I'll show those hacks a minefield the likes of which they've never seen.
Well, as long as everyone appreciates the work I'm doing for them, that's all right then.
Yes, yes, I'm sure it will be.
Right, I'd like you to get started right away.
That's the alarm. I assume you want me to start after this battle.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Good work out there, Argonaut. You've been doing an excellent job of holding down our flanks.
Thank you, Captain! I've been quite pleased myself with how things are going. The crew has been in such high spirits. Only...
Only what, Argonaut? It seems like you've found a good place.
Well, I would love to keep doing this, but... out there on my own, I really worry for the crew's safety.
That's very generous of you, Argonaut. What can I do to help?
Oh, well, you know, I was just thumbing through the technical manuals, and I'd just love a pair of new propellers. I'm not the fastest ship around, you know.
Gold-plated. I just think they'd complement my accoutrements ever so elegantly.

Fields.MenuText: I see. Well, I'll talk to the drydock engineering teams about that.
All right, Argonaut, it's starting to sound like this might not be for the crew.
Oh, but your armor plate looks so lovely with the cut of your deck as it is.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, thank you, Captain! You do spoil a girl so.
Oh, but of course it is, Captain! I simply want them to have the best and most powerful machinery driving them into battle and out.
Do you think so? I might need to show it a bit more, get a few more opinions on this first.
Let's see how nice you look firing some torpedoes at that approaching fleet.
@BATTLE
I suppose that couldn't hurt. I think you were about due for-
Let's! An old ensemble must have a fitting sendoff, after all.
You were right. The view is very nice from your deck. I can just see the moon beginning to peek through.
I know, dear. I'm usually right. But it is quite nice of you to say.
*ALARM*
Oh, drat, there's the dive alarm. Something must have happened while we were up here.
Wait, the dive alarm? Don't they know we're up here? Quick, get the hatch open!
Oh, don't be so dramatic, Captain! I can open the hatch from here, and we have time for one last look at the stars before we go under.

Fields.MenuText: Wait, how long does it take you to submerge? This doesn't seem practical.
All the same, if the enemy can see us, I'd rather be inside.
I forgot you could do that. I suppose I'll take your word for it.

Fields.DialogueText: You sound just like that admiral. Of course it's fine. I just can't be caught with my drawers down.
Oh, you and your worries. That's fine, I suppose.
Good to see you starting to trust me a bit, Captain. I assure you it's worth it.
Ah, there's that lovely moon! Now, hurry to the hatch, Captain. I'll meet you inside.
All right, see you in there. The battle should be a little faster than your dive.
I can still close the hatch from here, Captain.
@BATTLE
I've been thinking about your request for new propellers.
Oh yes, Captain? And do tell me what you've decided.
I haven't decided anything, but I've been talking to some of the drydocks, and next time we put in, we might be able to refit you.
Oh, that's lovely, Captain! Glad to hear it! The men will be so happy!
I'm sure. I hadn't really thought about the strain on them, until you brought it up to me.

Fields.MenuText: Of course. I'm so glad to have you here to point me in the right direction.
Yes, yes, I'm happy to know I can help the sailors under my command.
Sure you did. And I'm responsible for the current climate of world peace.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, we can't all be the beacon of empathy and understanding that I am, Captain.
They are blessed to have you, Captain. So reasonable and generous.
Oh, is the land war over? I hadn't heard. Then there should be no problem with getting my refit.
Keep up the minelaying and I'll make sure to make this a priority.
You mean after we deal with the source of this alarm, I imagine.
@BATTLE
Assuming we can make it work, they should last too. Gold doesn't rust or corrode in seawater - oddly well-suited for long hauls.
Oh, aren't the gold ones going to be so much more resplendent?
Ah! ... Yes, Captain, of course I did. If you're not on the cutting edge of fashi- I mean, technology, where even are you?
*ALARM*
To be clear, we're not talking about solid gold propellers - cost aside, my understanding is that the metal is too soft to be viable. But it's possible that some kind of filigree can be arranged.
That was certainly an interesting exercise. I was a little worried by the sign hanging on the wall.
Whyever so, Captain? "You will not be yourself" very neatly laid out the premise of today's workshop.
I'm simply saying that the phrasing was a little off-putting. Especially for a non... actor.
I thought it did a good job of laying out the premise, myself. Sure, I've taken a few shots to the head, but I still got the idea.
Thank you, Mr. Barchet. See, Captain? If you trust me, and you did, everything will turn out fine!
Can't argue with that, can you, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I'm pretty sure I can. A certain wantonness with explosives comes to mind.
I can see when I'm outnumbered. Thank you both again for including me in these activities.
After that exercise, I feel like I can argue with anything. Hey, there's an idea - why don't we do a debate next time?

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about, Captain. I am nothing if not careful.
Of course, Captain! You're always welcome aboard my decks.
Oh, I already have one of those planned in three exercises. But it was a lovely suggestion, Captain.
I hate to break this up, but we have an engagement in the next hour, ma'am.
Ah, yes. Ta, Captain! Places, everyone; we've a show to put on!
@BATTLE
Officer Barchet, you'll be happy to know that we should be putting ashore for a drydock soon.
Good to know, Captain! Maybe we can finally get the fire wires replaced.
Oh, I thought you'd be eager for the new propellers. I suppose wanting those fires to stop makes sense, though.
Why would I care about the propellers, Captain? This is a submarine. That wiring is what's going to kill us.
Oh, Argonaut made it sound like you were very excited about some new propulsion.
I'm sure she did. And a few new trinkets will certainly keep her happy for a while.
Well, hello there, officers. Deep in conversation again, I see? Don't let little old me interrupt you.
It's fine. We'd just finished up, actually.

Fields.MenuText: Anything new and interesting happening with you?
I was just telling Barchet about the new propellers.
I was actually just heading off ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, yes, I think I just found a dress that is absolutely divine! It has the most lovely silver accents.
Oh, won't they be so lovely? They might last us the whole war! Provided they don't go out of style, of course.
Oh, no, but I just got here! Please, stay; we can have coffee!
Oh, would you look at that? Proximity alarm. I guess we have to go.
Drat. Ah, well, let's get this fight over and then catch up.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... And that's when they decided to use me in the film, obviously.
You know, I knew I recognized your outline. Well, good to see that it's had such a positive effect on you.
Oh, yes, Captain, dear. Being discovered was the best thing for me. I have so many opportunities now.
A few less now that the war's on, I imagine? Probably puts a damper on filming?
You might think that, but now there are even more!
There were always scripts coming in, of course, but now they want to embed cameramen and everything.
I'm being pursued for "Against the Ghosts," I believe the working title is. Speaking of, how do you like this dress?

Fields.MenuText: As long as you don't start bringing cameramen and such aboard without asking. I don't want civilians in the way.
It's lovely, as is everything else in your closet. I'm sure it would suit you on the silver screen.
This is going to happen after we win, right? You aren't planning to try and tape the war. From a submarine.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, of course not, Captain! I would never do such things.
Shows what you know about fashion, Captain. My closet is full of ratty things from last season.
No, that would be foolish. Tape the war from inside a submarine, indeed!
All right, story time will have to wait. That alarm means we've got work to do.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, Argonaut, before I forget, I have some good news for you.
Oh, do tell! I could use a bit of positivity today.
Oh, is something the matter? Do you need help with anything?
What? Oh, no, Captain, but thank you. I just love receiving positive news.
Oh, well, then you'll be happy to know that there's a major dry dock we're headed towards that ought to be able to get you fitted with those new propellers.
Oh, Captain, that's splendid! I'll tell the men immediately. They'll be so thrilled!

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure they will, Argonaut. And I'm sure you'll be very happy that they're happy.
It was definitely their idea, right? We aren't putting gold propellers on a submarine for another reason, are we?
Yes, yes. Just be prepared for the refit when the time comes.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh of course, Captain! The safety and welfare of my crew is my primary concern.
No no, Captain! They're very concerned about the lack of accents to my structure!
Oh of course, Captain! I've been prepared since I saw them in the technical specifications.
Make sure you actually pay attention in the briefings, all right?
And you pay attention to the alarms, Captain. We've got a war to fight.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... Deal.
I've never seen you that animated during a briefing, Argonaut. You actually talked about tactics.
Well, if our tactics can benefit from my new propellers, then I will be a tactical genius.
It's nice to hear that change to your creed, whatever the reason.
It's not that I was ever opposed to planning sessions on principle, you understand. They were simply incredibly boring and useless.
Right. Of course they were. Anyway, it was excellent to have your input.
Anything that will get us to port faster, Captain. Even if it cuts into my rehearsal time.

Fields.MenuText: I think that's the biggest sacrifice I've ever seen you make.
You'd go that far? I had underestimated your commitment to your crew.
Well, that will be your cross to bear, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a person of great generosity and the lives of my men are everything to me.
What are a few acting sessions in the face of the greater war?
I'll have the script writers make a note of how much I suffered for this unfortunate war.
Well, I'll do my best to get you there as soon as possible.
Perfect, Captain! I shall look forward to it. Oh, but there's the alarm. One step at a time, I suppose.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And don't forget about the electrical systems, all right? I think the condensation is causing it.
Well, you would certainly know, wouldn't you? Don't worry, I won't forget.
Ah, there you are, Captain! I knew you'd come aboard, but I wasn't sure where you were.
Just talking to Officer Barchet. Dismissed, Officer.
Aye-aye, sir. Good luck to you both.
I'm so happy to see you and the good Mr. Barchet getting along so famously.
He's quite the conversationalist, once you get past the football metaphors.

Fields.MenuText: I get the feeling he'd be a lot happier if he was on a field than if he was running a submarine.
It's good you have someone who loves this ship and its crew as much as he does.
I'm glad I only have to talk to him down here.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, you've never seen him hard at work. They're going to have to pry him out of my bridge when the war ends.
I know. I'm very blessed to have someone helping me like him.
What a terrible thing to say! For shame, Captain!
If you hadn't chosen me, I think you might well have chosen him.
@BATTLE
Oh, I doubt he would have been nearly as accommodating as you've been. All that nonsense about fire wires...
*ALARM*
Let's get the crew to general quarters, shall we? And... do a sweep for fire, just in case.
Captain! Isn't there way to get the fleet moving any faster?
If there was, we'd have come up with it during the mission briefing.
No need to be snippy, Captain - a simple no would have sufficed. What if I go ahead on patrol?
We don't do that for a reason, remember? How about you stick to keeping the Morganas off our back.
Don't you tell me what to do, Captain! I could be excellent on patrol, and I'd find all the enemies.
Right. What I meant was that no one else can lay a minefield like you. We need you preventing the fleet from being followed.

Fields.MenuText: If we had any other way, I'd love to know you were keeping us safe by scouting ahead.
We've got plenty of fast, little ships to patrol ahead, so you can hang back.
I'm sure if we just stick to your plan, we'll be just fine.

Fields.DialogueText: Right, of course, but I have to do my magic to keep the enemy fleet off our feet.
Are you saying something about my figure, Captain? Because it is healthy and voluptuous, thank you very much!
Well, it was a pretty brilliant plan, if I do say so myself. I'm not sure I remember what it was, but I'll stick to it!
Of course. Now, do you mind getting the crew in order? We have to bust through a few more lines of Morganas.
Right! Places, everyone! The action will be starting soon!
@BATTLE
Are we there yet, Captain? It feels like we've been traveling for days! I just want to get to dry dock.
Yes.
Well, I can't wait any longer! I demand that... did you say yes?
I did. Would you mind surfacing so I can use the radio?
Of course, Captain! Anything you need. I simply must get my refit done!
All right, all right. We just have to smash the fleet that's gathered there. It looks like the Morganas knew we were coming.
Oh, no, I want to start now! Those inconsiderate witches!

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind terribly getting on the battle line, so we can push our way in?
I'm sure this is a plot by them specifically to make your life as miserable as possible.
How dare they! I, too, am filled with righteous anger at this outrage...

Fields.DialogueText: Don't talk to me like I'm a child, Captain. We have a war to fight here.
I know! They have it out for me because everyone knows I'm beautiful and they're a bunch of hideous hags.
Good! Let's take them apart! I want to be fitted for my propellers yesterday.
All right, let's get to it, then. No sense in waiting around.
@BATTLE
All right, Argonaut. We just need a defensive minefield, and then we can get you into dock.
This is unfair! Shouldn't someone who isn't getting a refit be in charge of that?

Fields.MenuText: You already agreed to do this. Can you just get out there and build us a nice wall of mines?
Don't try to shirk your duties. It's unfair to the rest of the fleet.
You won't need the propellers to hold off the foe. Just get out there and lay some mines so we can get to work.

Fields.DialogueText: This wait is intolerable! I can't believe there's no difference for those who are most in need! For shame, Captain.
This wait is intolerable! Don't you try to guilt me, Captain! I'm thinking of what's best for my crew here!
This wait is intolerable! You don't think I need them at all, do you, Captain? You think I'm just being frivolous!
Calm down, Argonaut. We don't have a lot of time. We need a minefield that will shelter this port long enough for us to take out approaching ships.
I don't care! I want to be in the docks now! I don't want to have to go out there!
What's all this...  Ah, ma'am, Captain, good to see you both.
Mr. Barchet, tell the Captain he is being unreasonable by not letting us dock immediately.
Actually, Ma'am, I came up to let you both know that the enemy has been sighted. We need to defend the port.
Damn it! All right, fine!
@BATTLE
Ooooh, that hits the spot. I can feel them buffing the corrosion off my underside now. Do you know what that feels like?
I honestly couldn't say. It's that good, hmm?
Worth the wait, certainly. I can't wait to see the new propellers spin.

Fields.MenuText: I've never known a Belle to get so happy about machinery this gaudy.

Fields.DialogueText: You would not believe how nice they'll look, not to mention how crisp they'll feel. And while I'm at it,  I really ought to have some AA guns as well.
We'll see about that.
You spoil me, Captain. I can't think of anything else I'd want more.
What about replacement wiring and a new dehumidifier?
I suppose, I suppose, as long as it all looks nice. And not the cheap stuff. Top of the line only!
I thought you might be interested. After all, your crew is everything to you.
Of course, Captain, of course! Where would I be without them?

Fields.MenuText: I hope we never have to find out. They're good sailors, and you're a good ship.
I hope we never find out, but you'll be sailing with me either way.

Fields.DialogueText: An accessory is only gaudy if it distracts from the beautiful whole! You'll find that quite impossible with me.

Fields.MenuText: How? I've never seen you swim before.

Fields.DialogueText: Nor would you ever, Captain! There aren't any cameras three hundred feet below sea level. No, I'll content myself with a look before we leave. Wouldn't want to be vain, now.

Fields.MenuText: They just might last us the war. If they survive.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that won't be any kind of problem with you and I at the helm! And if it is, I know you'll take pity on a poor girl who's lost her gold.
They're a little rough around the edges, but enough of a spin in the tumbler and they'll be true gems. Oh! While we're on the subject...
I do hope so! You've a generous soul, Captain... and you're no slouch on the battlefield, either. I should say you cut quite the figure.
